docs.lead_paragraph: A cavernous California warehouse that serves as an informal office building for the tech-enamored doesn’t comply with city regulations. But no one, including the city, wants to close it.
docs.abstract: Hacker Dojo, a cavernous warehouse in Mountain View, Calif, that serves as an informal office building for the tech-enamored, does not comply with city regulations; inhabitants are scrambling to raise money to save the space from being shut down; it is an example of the new work spaces that underlie the start-up culture of Silicon Valley.
docs.snippet: A cavernous California warehouse that serves as an informal office building for the tech-enamored doesn’t comply with city regulations. But no one, including the city, wants to close it....

docs.lead_paragraph: What human skills will become more valuable as computers take over more and more duties?
docs.abstract: David Brooks Op-Ed column explores skills that will increase in value as computers take over more duties from humans; holds enthusiasm, disciplined attention spans, and the ability to discern the essence of an idea are among the most promising traits.

docs.section_name: Technology; Education; New York and Region
docs.lead_paragraph: The New York City Board of Education is planning to provide online training for the city's 78,000 teachers starting next fall, Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy said yesterday. Mr. Levy issued a request for proposals from private companies to help the board create a Web site that would provide the course work. Teachers would be able to access the site 24 hours a day, making it a more convenient option for professional development than courses offered by local colleges or the United Federation of Teachers.
docs.abstract: Schools Chancellor Harold O Levy says New York City Education Board plans to provide online training for teachers starting next fall; seeks proposals from private companies to help board create Web site to provide course work; says United Federation of Teachers backs plan, which would not replace courses offered by union or local colleges; says courses are not intended for unlicensed teachers seeking certification (M)
docs.snippet: The New York City Board of Education is planning to provide online training for the city's 78,000 teachers starting next fall, Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy said yesterday.    Mr. Levy issued a request for proposals from private companies to h...
